instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_KBDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_KBDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_KBDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the keyboard backlight. When this is low or missing, the keyboard will not light up..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SMC_TPAD_RST_L: What is SMC_TPAD_RST_L? SMC_TPAD_RST_L is a signal that comes from the trackpad that can reset the SMC when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. The trackpad having corrosion from liquid damage is a very common cause of no light on the magsafe charger & the system not turning on, when the trackpad or trackpad cable is corroded and holding this line down. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
Guys,

The board has water damage.
The thing is "works" (turn on, get the login screen, but the keyboard and tracks doesn't), bc the board looks like a S****, i decide before start troubleshooting drop on the supersonicmachine.
Well, after that, the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> /S3 is missing.

Any hint at this point?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: USC knocked something off. Look at the board under the scope very closely

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: What is USC means?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: Ultrasonic cleaner. Never clean a board before prefroming localized reflows of the damaged areas.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
Yes, for sure. Like i said: After the USC, the S0/S3 is missing, but S5 still there.
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> is there 3.4 i get green light

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: Could be anything. Check all the usual, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and termination resistors, PPVRTC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>
Pin 1 = 0
Pin 2 = 0.90v
Pin 3 = 0
Pin 4 = GND
Pin 5 = 0
Pin 6 = 0
Pin 7 = 0
Pin 8 = 3.4V

<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>
Pin 1 = 3.3V
Pin 2 = 3.3V
Pin 3 = 0V
Pin 4 = 0.90V
Pin 5 = 3.34V
Pin 6 = 3.34V
Pin 7 = 0V
Pin 8 = 0V
Pin 12 = 0.4V
Pin 13 = 3.4V
Pin 14 = 0V
Pin 15 = 0V
Pin 16 = 0V

<CHIP>U6100</CHIP>
Pin 1 = 0V
Pin 2 = 3.34V
Pin 3 = 3.34V
Pin 4 = 0V
Pin 5 = 3.34V
Pin 6 = 3.34V
Pin 7 = 3.34V
Pin 8 = 3.34V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: By checking I meant for corrosion. Check if board is power cycling on L7520 preferably with a scope as multimeter can be to slow to catch the pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: Duke, i don't have scope. Have another way?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: Connect a LED with a 100 ohm resistor to the 5V output on L7520. Should be able to see it blink.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: If you don't want to spend any money go find some old CRT scope  for $20. Any 10MHz piece of crap will suffice.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: I just bought a scope and tested L7520 and i get small pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: Check PPVRTC, 32KHz from <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> pin 12? <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
Duke, i found a corrosion on Pin 4 ( <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_KBDBKLT</SIGNAL> ) J9515, so i removed.
Right now, i get my 5v back.
So, i tested <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_KBDBKLT</SIGNAL> PIN 4-3 short to ground, for see if i get some, and then the multimiter shows me 2.4 Ω.
So i start remove the component one by one, but i still get 2.4.

Any ideia?
Thank you for all your help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: Usually in the KBD keyboard connector or in the board in that area. Is the board Chiming and working again, KBD backlight is not critical of course. Can take out <DIODE>D7720</DIODE> to isolate the short and have the rest of the machine work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: I did that, but still

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: Still what? Does the machine even boot now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
The board works now. However, the system can't recognize the battery. I try another battery and i get the same thing.
I try to fix without ask you guys, but i'm stuck on this.
Any hint?

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: PPBUS voltage without battery? If it is 12.3V then it is probably a dead SMC or <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
I will try to explain what happen now:
If i take the SSD and let popup the mark folder, the battery works fine.
However, if i put back the SSD and boot the OS normally with the charge plugged the system can't find the battery.
sound's weird, right?

Answer your question, i get 12.39V with and without battery on PPBUS

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
What do you mean with battery works but not in the OS?
Do you mean that the system will keep on running even if you remove the AC adapter, but not while in OS?
Do you mean that the system will change the battery but not if you're in the OS? (Only orange light before boot into OS)
Do you mean that the system will only report the battery being there in the boot menu?

Very unlikely that booting into the OS changes anything about the battery, at best the interface is just not working properly. (I've seen on systems with no battery connected the Filevault login screen of a encrypted system showing 100% battery, this is not true)

Check if <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA is not going to ground, verify <RESISTOR>R5380</RESISTOR>/81 are up to specification.
Check voltage of <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>/SDA with the battery it came with plugged in, it should not be above 3.5V as that would mean the battery is killing the chips on the datalines.
Was there a lot of crap around the SMC before you threw it in the ultrasonic? You might try a reflow before you replace it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
It is just not seeing the battery. It will power on from AC and when you pull the charger it remains on. Powering on from the battery will not work.

Your SMC and/or <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> are dead. SMC is the more common.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
No Title

Take a look the videos:
with OS, don't hold the battery, just with charge
without OS (SSD) i can't take the charge and the battery hold works fine.
I know, seems crazy, however, you can see on the video i just upload.

Btw: The <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> is replaced

Video Link:

Let me know what you guys think

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
What the videos show me is that the OS is smart enough to go into suspend to make sure the user does not lose data, and the EFI/BIOS does not implement this.
This is not the issue and expected behaviour when battery readouts are failing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: So, what is the problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
Just the battery on
L7130: 11.97V both sides
F7140 : 11.97V both sides
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 11.73V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: You just don't want to hear that the SMC is dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
You wont be able to use that one as it's just the unprogrammed chip.

You need to find a donor board (exactly the same board number) from eBay or AliExpress and use the SMC from there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: [USER="289"]smiba[/USER] I just order a donor board. Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
SMC Replaced and works!
However, after a couple minutes the trackpad and keyboard stop work. I tested with another one and still.
Any idea where i can start check for see what happen?

J4813:
PIN 5 = 3.42
PIN 30 = 3.42V

F4800 = 12V both sides, but the schematics say is 16v is that right?
<SIGNAL>SMC_TPAD_RST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.42V

<CHIP>U8170</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL> = 0

I get just orange light
<RESISTOR>R5187</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<CHIP>U7001</CHIP> = 3.4V
 <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> PIN 14 <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.4V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: [USER="289"]smiba[/USER] any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: The usual issue is the trackpad flat cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
Yes, i tested and doesn't working.
The keyboard doesn't work too. Don't you think could be another thing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message:
No experience with this issue other then cable or trackpad issues. Maybe the USB traces are bad and the device gets disconnected due to too many failed transmissions.

Does it also show this issue when booting into OS X Recovery?
Will the trackpad and keyboard keep working in the boot drive selection? (So while its still in its EFI)

Most likely putting the device in sleep and then waking it will bring the trackpad and keyboard back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 Missing
threads.message: Try with a known good trackpad and cable. Trackpad must be connected for keyboard to work.
